title: i \*heart\* cheltenham!
content:
well, since [Bookman](http://web.archive.org/web/20150204060308/http:/typophile.com/node/17453)'s already been done (twice this month). I may just have to devote my efforts to Cheltenham [swash](http://web.archive.org/web/20150204060308/http:/typophile.com/wiki/swash). or maybe I can find some lost version of Clearface swash...

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150204060308im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Chelt01.gif)
author: paul d hunt

comments.content: I've always preferred Ludlow's Cheltenham swash characters, which is unusual. I tend to like ATF's versions of things in most cases.
do you have any samples of the Ludlow swash characters, Mark? I'd love to see 'em!

Sure thing:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150204060308im_/http:/typophile.com/files/chelt-cursive-ludlow.gif)

As far as I know, Ludlow only did these cursive caps, no lowercase variants.
Do you mean you prefer the ATF caps?
i think stewf's referring back to my blog on [bookman](http://web.archive.org/web/20150204060308/http:/typophile.com/wiki/bookman). you think this one's a bit more worthy or revival, s?
I wonder if the ATF swash caps were designed by Goodhue? I suspect so...

interesting. your ludlow swashes look like they've been designed to be non-kerning, similar to some bb&s swash caps that i put in the OT version of [LTC Caslon](http://web.archive.org/web/20150204060308/http:/www.p22.com/lanston/products/caslon.html).

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150204060308im_/http:/typophile.com/files/bbscaswsh.gif)
Ludlow had slanted matrices for italics, so could be.
Paul - Yes, I think Bookman is both oversaturated and dated. Cheltenham swashes are certainly antique, but I think the face would be more useful and relevant.
